thread.title: Jazz Port Townsend ventured all over the map
thread.title_full: Jazz Port Townsend ventured all over the map

author: Paul de Barros
title: Jazz Port Townsend ventured all over the map
text:
Jazz Port Townsend ventured all over the map   1:44 pm The annual festival included a Portuguese set by Brazilian vocalist Maucha Adnet; performances by Duduka Da Fonseca and Trio Da Paz; and stellar work from Regina Carter, Kim Nazarian and the Faculty All-Star Big Band. Seattle Times jazz critic Concert review 
It’s a testament to the power of Brazilian vocalist Maucha Adnet, who opened the Jazz Port Townsend concerts in McCurdy Pavilion on Friday (July 24), that she sang her entire set in Portuguese but the crowd still gave her a standing ovation. 
Adnet’s performance was one of several at the festival with a world music flavor, including programs by Trio Da Paz (led by Adnet’s husband, Duduka Da Fonseca) and by violinist Regina Carter, who ranged all over the atlas. 
Adnet sang Friday like Cezanne painted — in purples and oranges that surprised you with their blunt, unarguable honesty and quiet, organizational grace, often doing tunes unfamiliar to the crowd — Vinicius de Moraes’ “Pra Que Chorar,” Gilbert Gil’s “Eu Vim da Bahia” — yet still communicating. 
Carter, who followed, delighted the audience with Richard Bona’s African-inspired “Mandingo Street,” on which she sang as she bowed. Before soaring into the beautiful spiritual “I’m Going Home On This Morning’s Train,” Carter dialed up a field recording of the song on her mobile device. Most Read Stories A look at who the Mariners could move at the trade deadline 
Out in the Port Townsend clubs, pianist George Cables sparkled mischievously at the Cotton Building, where highlights included Chuck Deardorf rising up to the hanging vamp on Cable’s beautiful ballad, “Helen’s Song.” 
Saturday afternoon, 30-year-old Trio Da Paz offered more Brazilian percolation, with guitarist Romero Lubambo galloping through the spidery melody of his tune “Pro Flavio” with twinkling, pinprick accuracy. 
Vocalist Kim Nazarian (of New York Voices) followed with a spirited set that included a wonderful version of the breakup ballad, “Tell Him I Said Hello” and a couple of tunes that showcased her strong folk backbone, including a lovely version of Willie Nelson’s “Crazy” that had pianist Eric Reed channeling the flapping grace notes of Floyd Kramer. 
Festival artistic director John Clayton often invokes the idea of a “jazz family” in his introductions. Nazarian did him one better by bringing her actual family on stage, including her husband, Jay Ashby, playing trombone, and her son, Ian, singing the lead on the ‘50s hit, “Qué Será, Será,” a song the elderly crowd happily chimed in on. 
Tenor saxophonist Bob Mintzer closed the afternoon by conducting a set of his arrangements played by the Faculty All-Star Big Band, which included some warm brass writing on a quiet, Native American-inspired tune, “Original People.” Paul de Barros: 206-464-3247; pdebarros@seattletimes.com ; or follow him on Twitter @pdebarros
